metadata.title: Progress on implantable biofuel cell: Nano-carbon functionalization for enzyme immobilization enhancement

sections.text:
Biofuel cells are bio-electrochemical devices, which are suitable for the environmentally
friendly generation of energy. Enzymatic biofuel cell (EBFC) operates at ambient temperature and pH. Biofuel cells utilize vegetable and animal fluids (e.g. glucose) as a biofuel to produce energy. Fundamental part of each Glucose biofuel cell (GBFC) is two bioelectrodes which their surface utilizes as an enzyme immobilized site. Glucose oxidase (GOx) or glucose dehydrogenase (GDH) were immobilized on bioanode and oxidize glucose while oxygen reduced in biocathode using immobilized laccase or bilirubin oxidase in order to generate sufficient power. Glucose biofuel cells are capable to generate sufficient power for implanted devices. The key step of manufacturing a bioelectrode is the effective enzyme immobilization on the electrode surface. Due to the thin diameter of carbon nanomaterials, which make them accessible to the enzyme active sites, they are applicable materials to establish electronic communication with redox enzymes. Carbon nanomaterials regenerate the biocatalysts either by direct electron transfer or redox mediators which serve as intermediated for the electron transfer. Nano-carbon functionalization is perfectly compatible with other chemical or biological approaches to enhance the enzyme functions in implantable biofuel cells. Efficient immobilization of enzyme using the functionalized nano-carbon materials is the key point that greatly increases the possibilities of success. Current review highlights the progress on implantable biofuel cell, with focus on the nano-carbon functionalization for enzyme immobilization enhancement in glucose/O2 biofuel cells.
Keyword: Nanomaterials; Graphene; Carbon nanotubes; Glucose/O2; Energy; Biocatalyst

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Biofuel cells are a subclass of fuel cells utilizing biocatalysts to generate power (Plamen
Atanassov et al., 2007). These bio electrochemical device convert chemical energy to electrical energy employing biochemical pathways (Bullen et al., 2006). While an electrical action might reason a biological response, the reverse pathway, such as utilizing lactose (from cheese making) to supply electrical equipment’s power is also true. These reactions use biological processes to generate electricity (Davis & Higson, 2007). The suitable fuel oxidized at the anode and released the electrons which reduce the oxygen in the other side at the cathode. The catalyst in biofuel cells could be a microorganism (e.g.; Baker’s yeast) or an enzyme which directly convert the carbohydrates chemical energy into electric energy (Allen & Bennetto, 1993; Sisler, 1971).
Since biological fuel cells use chemical energy resources, they can be small, and supply
their required fuel from the biological environment, living organism (e.g. Glucose from the blood stream) or plant (Mano et al., 2002). The type of biofuel cell catalyst defines their type into three main groups; microbial fuel cells, enzymatic fuel cells and mitochondria fuel cells, which the last one is an intermediate group based on organelles (Chekin et al., 2013; Scherbahn et al., 2014). The microbial biological fuel cells employ microorganisms such as; Escherichia coli, Enterobacter aero-genes, C. butyricum, Clostridium acetobutylicum and Clostridium perfringens. The mitochondria is an electrical current generator in the third group of BFCs while the enzymatic BFCs employ complex structure comprising proteins called enzymes oxidize renewable energy sources with no emissions of greenhouse gas (F. Chekin et al., 2012; Krikstolaityte et al., 2013; Minteer et al., 2012; Zebda et al., 2012). Long lifetimes (up to five years) of microbial biofuel cells are their key benefit (Fereshteh Chekin, Samira Bagheri, et al., 2012; Moon et al., 2006) along with their ability to of complete oxidization of simple sugars to carbon dioxide (Bond & Lovley, 2005). However the low power densities (i.e. Generated power per unit surface area of electrodes, usually reported in Watts/cm 2 ) of microbial biofuel cells due to their slow electron transport across cellular membranes limit their benefits (Palmore & Whitesides, 1994). On the other hand, enzymatic biofuel cells typically have a shorter lifetime (typically 7–10 days) due to the fragile nature of the enzyme and partially oxidize the biofuel while generating higher power densities (though lower than the common fuel cells) (Barton et al., 2004; Kim et al., 2006). Enzymes overcome the separator membrane dependency by their
valuable specificity property. Recent research by the Minteer group has applied a quaternary ammonium salt-treated Nafion membrane to in situ immobilization of the enzymes at the electrode surface (Christine M. Moore et al., 2004). The key step of construction the biological fuel cells is studying electron-transfer kinetics of the mediated bioelectrocatalysis (Anthony Turner et al., 1987). Owning to high catalytic activity, selectivity and increased power generation, isolated enzymes are attractive catalysts for fuel cells (Carstensen & Marquis, 1986; Moore et al., 2005).

sections.heading: 1.1. Glucose/O2 biofuel cells
sections.text:
Presence of biofuels such as glucose in fluids of animals and vegetables provide required
fuel for power generation bio implants (Zebda, Gondran, et al., 2011). Glucose biofuel cell (GBFC) was made of two enzyme immobilized bioelectrodes. The GBFC utilizing glucose oxidase (GOx) (EC 1.1.3.4) for glucose oxidation and utilize laccase (EC 1.10.3.2) for the dioxygen reduction or glucose dehydrogenase (GDH) (EC 1.1.5.9) and bilirubin oxidase (EC 1.3.3.5) to generate sufficient power from a mammal's body fluids, respectively (Figure 1) (Zebda, Gondran, et al., 2011). The glucose oxidized in bio-anode to produce d-gluconolactone and electrons while in the other side of BFC, the oxygen would be reduced in the bio-cathode and produce H2O (Bahartan et al., 2012; Brunel et al., 2007). The generated power of the single implanted enzymatic GBFC can light up an LED or power a digital thermometer (Zebda et al., 2013b).
molecular oxygen will be the ultimate electron acceptor in the cathode which reduce the water in neutral or slightly acidic media.

sections.heading: 1.2. Glucose oxidase
sections.text:
Glucose oxidase (β-D-glucose: oxygen 1-oxidoreductase, EC 1.1.3.4) is a nucleic acid
containing protein (flavoprotein) that transfer electron to oxygen and catalyze D-glucono-deltalactone and hydrogen peroxide biosynthesize by oxidizing the first hydroxyl group of β-Dglucose. The most common source of glucose oxidase is the fungus Aspergillus niger, which isolated enzyme utilized for industrial applications such as glucose monitoring. The nigerderived Glucose oxidase (GOx) is highly substrate specific for glucose while other GOxs are capable of oxidizing other sugars, including maltose. Enormous studies have reported higher glucose specificity of GOx and its application to measure the amount of glucose in the mixture with other sugars (Keilin & Hartree, 1948).GOx is a pH sensitive enzyme (Kleppe, 1966). Debility of native GOx to handover electrons to electrode, make this enzyme a valuable candidate to be applied in third-generation glucose sensor structure by connecting the redox center of enzymes to the electrode. In order to approach this connection, several molecular wires, such as osmium complex-linked polymers (Vijayakumar et al., 1996), artificial cofactor derivatives (Willner & Willner, 2001), thienoviologens (Albers et al., 1997), CNTs (Tsai et al., 2005), or nanofibers (Vamvakaki et al., 2006) employed. Figure 2 reveals the cyclic voltammograms for co-immobilization of PPD and GOx at the GC/CNT/PB electrode. One of the alternative enzymes which is capable of replacing the Glucose oxidase is Glucose dehydrogenases that will be explained in details.
Figure 2. Cyclic voltammograms of GC/CNT/PB modified electrode in phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) containing 5 mM phenylenediamine and 10 mg/mL GOx at a scan rate of 50 mV/s (Yao et al., 2012).

sections.heading: 1.3. Glucose dehydrogenase
sections.text:
Glucose dehydrogenases belong to oxidoreductases family that transfer electrons to
numerous natural and synthetic electron acceptors instead of oxygen and classified according to employed redox cofactors. These non-protein component and primary electron acceptor cofactors are, Nicotine adenine dinucleotide (NAD), Pyrroloquinoline quinone (PQQ) and Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD).

sections.heading: 1.3.1. Pyrroloquinoline Quinone Glucose dehydrogenase
sections.text:
Pyrroloquinoline quinone (PQQ) is the third common redox cofactor found in enzymes,
which only biosynthesis in the ribosome of prokaryots during an unknown pathway. Quinoprotein GDH (EC 1.1.5.2) subdivided to at least two separate groups of GDHs: PQQ GDH-A which binds to the membrane and PQQ GDH-B which dissolved in water, both utilize PQQ as the redox cofactor. In bacteria, the PQQ GDH-A is the terminal oxidation of glucose in the respiratory chain. PQQ GDHs are the most interesting enzyme in industry among other PQQ-
harboring enzymes. The PQQ GDH-B utilized in rapid glucose sensing due to its higher catalytic efficiency compare to GOx activity (more than 25 times) while reporting more fetal errors compare to GOx. (Oubrie et al., 1999).

sections.heading: 1.3.2. Nicotine Adenine Dinucleotide (Phosphate)-Dependent Glucose Dehydrogenase
sections.text:
Dehydrogenase Glucose-1-dehydrogenase [NAD(P) GDH, EC 1.1.1.47] found in the
massive amount of prokaryotes and eukaryotes. The β-D-glucose:NAD(P)+1- oxidoreductase enzyme transfers the electron of the hydroxyl group of glucose to NAD+ or NADP+ (first electron acceptor) and oxidize the glucose. While most NAD(P) GDHs use specifically glucose as a substrate, some of them are unable to recognize the second hydroxyl group and react with mannose, 2-amino-2-deoxy- D-glucose, and glucosamine instead of glucose (Giardina et al., 1986). The extracted NAD(P) GDH from Bacillus megaterium utilized to monitor the blood sugar. Figure 3A shows the obtained cyclic voltammograms. The first voltammogram (Figure 3A/a) reveal no peak due to absence of substrate (glucose). Addition of substrate to the supporting electrolyte shows an irreversible peak at about 760 mV at GDH/PAMAM/GCE (Figure 3A/b), due to NADH oxidation to NAD+ catalyzed by enzyme at PAMAM modified GCEs. Light exposure toward the electrode surface might slightly increase the current peak (Figure 3A/c). After polymerizing HT, GDH was immobilized onto poly-HT/PAMAM/GCE to study its electrochemical and photoelectrochemical responses to glucose via cyclic voltammetric method that represented in figure 4B. The anodic peak at about 210 mV with a shoulder at 120 mV in the presence of NAD+ as reason of polymeric HT oxidation were presented in the first cyclic voltammogram (Figure 3B/a). The current peak would increase due to NADH electrocatalytic oxidation to NAD+ in the presence of glucose (Figure 3B/b) while the light exposure to the electrode surface enhance this peak current largely (Figure 3B/c). Studying the cyclic voltammogram of GDH/PAMAM/GCE (about 760 mV) and the GDH/polyHT/PAMAM/GCE (about 300 mV), reveal the decrease of 460 mV at GDH/polyHT/PAMAM/GCE. Furthermore, exposing the electrode surface of GDH/polyHT/PAMAM/GCE would increase the electrocatalytic oxidation of NADH current peak (Figure 3B/c).
Figure 3. Cyclic voltammograms of (A) GDH/PAMAM/GCE and (B) GDH/polyHT/PAMAM/GCE in the presence of 10 mM NAD+ and (a) in the absence, (b) in the presence of 10 mM glucose without irradiation and (c) b with irradiation. Supporting electrolyte: 0.1 M PBS (pH 7.0) (Dilgin & Gokcel, 2015).

sections.heading: 1.3.3. Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide Dependent Glucose Dehydrogenase
sections.text:
The FAD-dependent GDHs (FAD GDH, EC 1.1.99.10) are well-known due to their use
in sensor applications. The cyclic voltammograms of the ferrocene polymeric mediator and FAD-GDH in phosphate buffered saline (PBS) reported in Figure 4. Symmetric anodic and cathodic peaks observed in the lack of glucose due to ferrocene moieties of the polymeric mediator oxidation and reduction. Addition of 2.5 mM glucose affectedly changes the cyclic voltammogram by major decreasing of the cathodic peak and increasing in the anodic peak which is the typical respond of enzyme-dependent catalyzer in the presence of glucose. Increasing the glucose concentration to 5.0 mM will increase the cathodic peak as well. The electron transfer from FADH2 to the ferrocene moieties and reduce it to ferrocenium which reoxidize again by transferring the electrons to the electrode.
Figure 4. Cyclic voltammograms: 1.5mg/mL FAD-GDH, 9 mg/mL ferrocene polymeric mediator in 0.01M pH7.4 PBS, scan rate 5 mV/s, without (solid line), with 2.5 mM glucose (broken line) & 5.0 mM glucose (dotted line) (Cardosi & Liu, 2012).

sections.heading: 1.4. Implantable biofuel cells and their applications
sections.text:
Implantable biofuel cells produce electricity from the electrochemical glucose and
oxygen reaction. In theory, the constant supply of glucose and oxygen together in provide an unlimited source of power generation (Kerzenmacher et al., 2008; Kloke et al., 2012) which can power implants like cardiac pacemakers. The suitable glucose fuel cells for implantation classified based on their electrocatalyst which facilitate the electrode reactions and divided into three main types; isolated enzymes such as glucose oxidase (Mano et al., 2003; A Termehyousefi et al., 2015; Zebda et al., 2013a) or abiotic electrocatalysts such as platinum (Kerzenmacher et al., 2008; Kloke et al., 2012) and microbial catalysts have a minor role for the application in implantable glucose fuel cells due to high risk of infection (Inmann & Spensley, 2013). Up to now, no functional method that isolates the power from the body is available, despite attempts to use the See beck thermos-electric effect, vibrations or body movements. Thus, applying glucose fuel cells which generate power, using two common substrates in physiological fluids (glucose and dissolved oxygen) seems more promising. In this case, the enzyme wired electrically to the redox mediators. Recent studies have reported few enzyme-based biofuel cells which are
functional in vivo. The challenging issues are implanting the biocatalytic electrodes and extracting the electrical power from small living (Halamkova et al., 2012).
Glucose fuel cells were considered as an interesting potential power source for implanted
devices, since they utilize the available glucose and dioxygen in the ECF to generate power. First studies by Drake and colleagues (1970) suggest that an abiotic catalysts could efficiently power an implanted medical devices (Drake et al., 1970). GBFCs employ catalysts enzymes which electrically wired by redox mediators (Cracknell et al., 2008; Deng et al., 2008; Habrioux et al., 2008; Togo et al., 2008). Although the MFCs can apply to generate the static power in large scales (Ishii et al., 2008), the enzymatic biofuel cell may employ in vivo for powering small implantable devices like biosensors due to their low power requirements (Heller, 2004; Osman et al., 2011).
With the aim of investigating the sufficient power supply of GBFCs to support electronic
devices, especially implantable medical devices, enzyme-based biofuel cells implanted into living lobsters were assessed (Zebda, Gondran, et al., 2011). Series connecting the two implanted biofuel cells in lobsters “living battery” were capable of generating up to 1.2 V open circuit voltage (Voc). In the same way, a set of five series connected cells, filled with human serum solution might generated Voc of 3 V which can easily supply the required power of a pacemaker. Normal human physiological glucose concentration and condition during resting or performing physical exercises can grantee the sustainable operation of the pacemaker. These two system models provide a land scape of future application of GBFCs in sensing, information processing and wireless transmission devices in military service, homeland security, environmental monitoring and biomedical applications. The first prototype of the pacemaker activated by the electrical energy transformed from physiological fluids open the path for future implantable medical devices (MacVittie et al., 2013). While the dissolved enzymes are only stable for days, immobilizing them on the electrode surface increase their stability by months (Christine M. Moore et al., 2004).
Hereby, we reviewed the applicable enzymes in glucose/O2 biofuel cells, structures of
carbon nanomaterials such as CNTs and graphene and focused on the application of functionalized and hybrid carbon based nanomaterials on biofuel cells.
2. Carbon nanomaterials
The carbon nanomaterials have been reported firstly in the mid-eighties, and up to now
numerous amount of the research activity have been held on it. As a result of their extraordinary chemical, electrical, thermal, and mechanical properties, lots of attentions were attracted toward carbon nanomaterials. Broad spectrum applications in era of composite materials, energy storage and conversion, sensors, drug delivery, field emission devices and nanoscale electronic components have been discovered ever since (Kelemen et al., 2012; Amin TermehYousefi et al., 2014). New members of carbon nanomaterials family have stepped on the scene such as CNTs and graphene.

sections.heading: 2.1. Carbon nanotubes (single wall, multi wall)
sections.text:
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are cylindrical nanostructure allotropes of fullerene structural
family with valuable unique properties for nanotechnology, electronics, optics, and other fields of materials science and technology (Ramimoghadam et al., 2014; Szwacki, 2008; Y. Wang et al., 2009). The extreme bonding among the atoms and high aspect ratios of tubes provide unique properties of CNTs. A CNT can be as long as hundreds of microns while still remind as thin as a few nanometers.
Another aspect of interest in the field of CNTs is conductivity. The combinations of N
and M (twisting indicating parameters of the nanotube) in CNTs structure make it highly conductive, and therefore it called to be metallic. Their chirality (degree of twist) and diameter control their conductivity efficiency and causing them electrically either semi-conducting or metallic. The model of graphene sheet which rolled up to form the carbon nanotubes, divers the characteristics of CNTs and causing it behave either semiconductor or metallic.
Although there is numerous variety of CNTs, they classified as single-walled (SWNTs)
or multi-walled nanotubes (MWNTs). The SWNTs only consist of one layer and look like a normal straw, while the MWNTs are group of nested tubes gathering and increasing the diameters constantly. They sort from a double-walled nanotube consisting one outer and one inner tube to more than 100 tubes surrounded each other. The interatomic forces held the distance of each neighboring tubes steady and constant.
The usual location of enzyme active site which was surrounded deep in the protein shell,
prevent the easy electronic connection between the electrode and active site of the enzyme lead to reduce the power density of the EBFC compare to inorganic fuel cells (Ying Liu & Dong,
2007). Therefore, CNTs mostly utilized by researchers to both increase the electrode surface area ratio and decrease the resistance against the electron transfer (Fereshteh Chekin, Jahan‐Bakhsh Raoof, et al., 2012; Gao et al., 2007; Li et al., 2008).

sections.heading: 2.2. Graphene
sections.text:
Graphene, nano two-dimensional (2D) substructure of carbon with unbelievable surface
area of about 2630 m 2 g −1 (about the size of a football stadium), possess unique physicochemical properties (high surface area, excellent conductivity, high mechanical strength, and ease of functionalization and mass production) (Shao et al., 2010; Stoller et al., 2008). Graphene can be called as the ‘mother of all carbon forms’ (Geim & Novoselov, 2007). Some studies reported the conductivity of graphene 64 mS cm −1 using a four-point probe method (approximately 60 times more than that of SWCNTs) (Alwarappan et al., 2009; Dai et al., 2007). Unlike CNTs, graphene do not suffer from disadvantages such as; residual metallic impurities that are inherent to the CVD fabrication process and have hindered their exploitation (Banks et al., 2006; Ji et al., 2010). In consequence of Graphene electrical conductivity, large surface area, unique heterogeneous electron transfer and charge carrier rates, widely applicable electro-catalytic activity, and low fabrication costs, it is a suitable applicable for electrochemical implementation (Brownson & Banks, 2010; F Chekin et al., 2012; Chen et al., 2010; Liang & Zhi, 2009; Pumera, 2009). Consequently, graphene was introduced as a favorable electrode material alternative in various applications in order to enhance specific technological fields and particularly the energy storage and generation fields. All these unique properties promising the applications of graphene energy related issues. Utilizing graphene to develop the existing knowledge and current techniques, groundbreaking performance is expected to surpass that already achieved whilst at the same time proving to be a greener and more energy efficient alternative (Brownson et al., 2011).

sections.heading: 2.3. Graphene quantum dot
sections.text:
Graphene quantum dots (GQD) are zero-dimensional graphene particles with the
characteristics of both graphene and carbon dots (CDs) (Mueller et al., 2010; Shen, Zhu, Yang, Zong, et al., 2012; Yan et al., 2010). Their size range from 3nm to 20 nm and consisting not more than 5 layers of graphene sheets (Shen, Zhu, Yang, & Li, 2012; Z. Zhang et al., 2012). Similar to geraphene, GQDs also have a high surface area and better surface grafting due to π-π
conjugation (Shen, Zhu, Yang, & Li, 2012). in addition, GQDs have low toxicity, excellent conductivity and solubility, strongly luminescent and biocompatibility (L. Wang et al., 2014). These novel properties of GQDs and their edge effects facilitate the direct electron transfer from enzyme active site to the electrode and suitable substrate for enzyme immobilization (Q. Liu et al., 2007; Sun et al., 2013). These properties of GQDs, attract the attention of researchers for the application of this 0D graphene kind for the biomedical applications such as third generation biosensors and biofuel cells (Zhao et al., 2011).

sections.heading: 3. Functionalized carbon nanomaterials for biofuel cells
sections.text:
The key step of fabricating an ideal enzymatic electrode to utilize in BFC, is an effective
enzymes immobilization (Tan et al., 2009). Furthermore, dissolved enzymes are usually active from a few hours to a few days. Trapping the enzyme in hydrogels and binding it to the electrode surfaces, might extend the enzymes lifetime to 7-20 days. Though, recent research at Saint Louis University increase the lifetimes of enzyme up to year by using hydrophobic modified micellar polymers to immobilize the enzyme on the surface of electrode (Christine M. Moore et al., 2004).
Functionalized carbon nanomaterials display excellent film-forming ability, good
adhesion, high mechanical strength, and susceptible to chemical modifications thanks to the existence of reactive functional groups (hydroxyl or amino groups) and widely used for enzymes immobilization (Huang et al., 2002; Luo et al., 2005; M. Zhang et al., 2004; Q. Zhou et al., 2007), crosslinking (Wei et al., 2002; M. Zhang et al., 2004) and dip-coating (Y. Liu et al., 2006). Functionalized carbon nanomaterials covalently bound to proteins, DNA, or small molecules (Martínez et al., 2010). Figure 5, shows the alternative method of immobilizing redox mediators onto CNTs using coating polymers.
Figure 5. Main procedures for the combination of redox mediators and CNTs: (a) aryldiazonium reduction, (b) 1,3 dipolar cycloaddition of azomethine ylides, (c) esterification of carboxylic acids, (d) electro-polymerization of pyrroles, (e) osmiumbased hydrogel adsorption, (f) π-stacking of pyrene groups (Holzinger et al., 2012a).

sections.heading: 3.1. Carbon nanotubes
sections.text:
The growing interest and attention to use CNTs is respond to its attractive characterizes
such as; the structural particularity, the conductivity and ability to decorate it with functional groups for the biomolecules immobilization (Holzinger et al., 2012a). Moreover, the oriented immobilization of enzyme on carbon nanotube was carried out to enhance the direct electron transfer (Fujita et al., 2014). The possibility to functionalize carbon nanotubes by attaching specific docking sites for enzymes via electro-generated polymer or pyrene derivatives exhibiting p-stacking interactions were reported (Bourourou et al., 2013; Zebda, Gondran, et al., 2011). Therefore the modified electrode using CNTs, reveal so many anchoring sites in order to immobilize hydrogenase (McDonald et al., 2007). Two common functional groups used to functionalized CNTs are carboxylic groups (Lojou, 2011) and amino groups (Hoeben et al., 2008), which effectively bind the enzymes into the CNTs structure. In figure 6a, are the comparative CV curves for H2 oxidation with Df Hase adsorbed on the long SWCN-CO2H (blue
curves) and on the short SWCN-cut (red curves) coatings, respectively. Based on the diverse applied CNT, different behavior observed. SWCN-CO2H coating shows no electron transfer for H2 oxidation in the lack of redox mediators, while high catalytic current for direct H2 oxidation approached using SWCN-cut. The direct electron transfer, provide evidences that the enzyme covered the film but not oriented. Addition of redox mediator increases the catalytic current during the adsorption of hydrogenase onto SWCN-cut. Thus, two groups of hydrogenases at SWCN-cut coatings suggested: one including the distal FeS cluster directly connected company with the carbon material, and another one which accessible only via a redox mediator. In order to efficiently generate higher amount of electrically connected enzymes, we should encapsulate the hydrogenases in the CNTs network before immobilizing it onto the graphite electrode. Remarkably, addition of the SWCN-cut, while the quantity of immobilized hydrogenase is stable, will increase the DET current, whereas the mixed direct/mediated current remained constant. Therefore, it is suggested that increase in the quantity of SWCN-cut will connect more hydrogenase molecules to the carbon nanotube materials directly.
Figure 6. Catalytic H2 oxidation by Desulfovibrio fructosovorans [NiFe]
hydrogenase adsorbed at carbon nanotube coated PG electrodes (S = 0.126 cm2). (A) Characteristic CV curves in 10 mM phosphate buffer, pH 7.6 under H2 in the absence (bold lines) and presence (fine lines) of 120 μM MV2+ for adsorbed hydrogenase at SWCN-CO2H (blue lines) and SWCN-cut (red lines) coated PG electrodes. The sweep rate was 2 mV s−1 and the amount of nanotubes was 4 μg. Schematic illustrations of the adsorption of hydrogenase, hence the electron transfer process, onto a PG electrode coated with SWCN-CO2H (B) and SWCN-cut (C). Hydrogenase and the distal [4Fe–4S] cluster are depicted by the sphere and the square inside, respectively (Pandelia et al., 2010).

sections.heading: 3.2. Graphene
sections.text:
Graphene has a number of functional groups moieties on its surface, such as; carboxylic,
ketonic, quinonic and C-double bond; length as m-dash. It is expected that functionalized
graphene induce the electron communication between electrode surface and enzymes (Shan et al., 2009). Among the mentioned functional groups, the carboxylic and ketonic groups are reactive and can easily covalently bind to GOx. In the same way, extended C-double bond; length as m-dash distributed in graphene is capable of transferring electrons (Jung & Chu, 2014). Furthermore, GO contains so many oxygen functional groups which might connect to the GOx free amino group in the same manner as significant carboxylic functional groups (Y. Liu et al., 2010). A GO sheet edges surrounded by plenty of carboxylic functional groups while other oxygen functional groups covering the plane. Unfortunately, existence of oxygen functional groups moderates the GO sheet electrical conductivity. Electrochemical methods is a promising technique to detach most of the oxygen functional groups from surface to improve the electrical conductivity(Guo et al., 2009). Figure 7 demonstrate the electrochemical setup and the optical pictures of the graphite electrode and the graphene oxide suspension prior and subsequently after electrochemical reduction.
Figure 7. Experimental setup demonstrate and the optical pictures of the graphite electrode and the graphene oxide suspension prior (a, c) and subsequently after (b, d) electrochemical reduction. The electrochemical reduction potential of the exfoliated graphene oxide dispersion at a graphite electrode was 1.5 V vs SCE (Guo et al., 2009).

sections.heading: 4. Hybrid carbon nanomaterials for biofuel cells
sections.text:
Considering the improvement in biofuel cell performance afforded by the use of hybrid
bioelectrodes nanoparticles, one can hypothesize that the metallic species can enhance either the
catalytic rate or the electron transfer process (Aquino Neto et al., 2015). The most used metallic nano species used to manufacture hybrid carbon nanomaterials for biofuel cell are; Au nanoparticles (Aquino Neto et al., 2015), Zn nanoparticles (Jensen et al., 2012), Pt nanoparticles (Aquino Neto et al., 2014) and TiO2 nanoparticles (Yang et al., 2014). Coating the CNT electrodes with polypyrrole-methyl viologen encapsulate it by hydrogenases while at the same time transfer the electron between the electrode and the NiFe active site of the hydrogenase. The higher the electroactive area of CNT electrode, the higher the yields of deposited redox polymers and surface concentrations of wired enzyme. Further studies prove that increasing the thickness of CNT film, increasing the catalytic currents for hydrogen oxidation too (Figure 8).
biocathode. Figure 9A shows that glucose oxidation induce the catalytic oxidation at about +0.19 V (vs. SEC) will the maximum electrocatalytic current on NGPs-based bioanode reached to 395 μA cm − 2 . In contrast, the electrocatalytic reduction current start from + 0.55 V (vs. SEC) and record −155 μA cm − 2 as its maximum current. Therefore, the glucose electro-oxidation demonstrates higher current density than oxygen electro-reduction. In addition, the reported current plateaus are highly depended on the mass transport diffusion of glucose and oxygen. Figure 9B shows the performance of NGPs-based glucose/O2 BFC.
Figure 9. (A) Polarization curves obtained in a phosphate buffered solution for the bioanode GOx/NGPs-modified GC electrode in a 10 mM glucose solution (dashed line) and for the biocathode laccase/NGPs-modified GC electrode in air-saturated solution (solid line). (B) Polarization (○) and performance (●) curves of the assembled NGPs-modified GC electrode based glucose/O2 biofuel cell. (Zheng et al., 2010a).

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion and future work
sections.text: The applications of enzymatic biofuel cells are attractive, while limited in some aspects. In order to overcome the challenges of enzymatic biofuel cells, including a short lifetime of enzyme and poor electron transfer between enzyme active sites and electrode surface, a series of modifications should be followed. Among all, the most important one is to enhance the immobilization and stability of the enzyme using novel nano-carbon materials. Carbon nanostructures integrated into the enzyme active site to improve the electron transfer between enzyme redox and electrodes due to their excellent electronic properties and high surface area. Recent developments in functionalizing the nano-carbon materials and enzyme immobilization, appears to be promising due to their solutions to overcome the present bottle-neck challenges by enhancing the lifetime of enzymes, while facilitating the diffusion of water, substrates, and ions to the modified electrode surfaces. Better improvements and further developments of nanocarbon materials will expedite the development of enzymatic biofuel cells, which will result in high performance biofuel cells to take a role in the dynamic energy market.

metadata.abstractText: Biofuel cells are bio-electrochemical devices, which are suitable for the environmentally friendly generation of energy. Enzymatic biofuel cell (EBFC) operates at ambient temperature and pH. Biofuel cells utilize vegetable and animal fluids (e.g. glucose) as a biofuel to produce energy. Fundamental part of each Glucose biofuel cell (GBFC) is two bioelectrodes which their surface utilizes as an enzyme immobilized site. Glucose oxidase (GOx) or glucose dehydrogenase (GDH) were immobilized on bioanode and oxidize glucose while oxygen reduced in biocathode using immobilized laccase or bilirubin oxidase in order to generate sufficient power. Glucose biofuel cells are capable to generate sufficient power for implanted devices. The key step of manufacturing a bioelectrode is the effective enzyme immobilization on the electrode surface. Due to the thin diameter of carbon nanomaterials, which make them accessible to the enzyme active sites, they are applicable materials to establish electronic communication with redox enzymes. Carbon nanomaterials regenerate the biocatalysts either by direct electron transfer or redox mediators which serve as intermediated for the electron transfer. Nano-carbon functionalization is perfectly compatible with other chemical or biological approaches to enhance the enzyme functions in implantable biofuel cells. Efficient immobilization of enzyme using the functionalized nano-carbon materials is the key point that greatly increases the possibilities of success. Current review highlights the progress on implantable biofuel cell, with focus on the nano-carbon functionalization for enzyme immobilization enhancement in glucose/O2 biofuel cells. Keyword: Nanomaterials; Graphene; Carbon nanotubes; Glucose/O2; Energy; Biocatalyst
metadata.creator: Elsevier
